dt: {bc}the state produced by the establishment of one or more pathogenic agents (such as a bacteria, protozoans, or viruses) in or on the body of a suitable host
{bc}an act or process of {d_link|infecting|infect} something or someone
{bc}the establishment of a pathogen in its host after invasion
{bc}an infectious agent or material contaminated with an infectious agent

dt.t: … that notion that the {wi}infection{/wi} was all in the air, that there was no such thing as contagion from the sick people to the sound …
It may not be uninteresting to add, that this case I vaccinated with {wi}infection{/wi} taken from a secondary pock on the arm of her sister …

dt: {bc}the communication of emotions or qualities through example or contact

dt.t: But immediately she resisted this intolerable fear as an {wi}infection{/wi} from her husband's way of thinking.

dt: {bc}the emotion or quality that is communicated

dt.t: … as the evening wore on, she caught the {wi}infection{/wi} of their excitement …
Besides, I know what sort of a mind I have placed in communication with my own: I know it is one not liable to take{wi} infection{/wi} …

dt: {bc}the act or result of {d_link|corrupting|corrupt:1} someone's morals, character, etc.

dt.t: … it is at least as difficult to stay a moral {wi}infection{/wi} as a physical one …
… they could not know the origin—or the depth—of his susceptibility to the {wi}infection{/wi} of power.

et: Middle English {it}infeccioun{/it} "morbid condition of a body part, disease, contamination," borrowed from Anglo-French & Late Latin; Anglo-French {it}infeccioun, enfection,{/it} borrowed from Late Latin {it}infectiōn-, infectiō{/it} "influence, process of dyeing, communication of disease, contamination," from Latin {it}infec-,{/it} variant stem of {it}inficere{/it} "to dye, discolor, taint, contaminate with disease" + {it}-tiōn-, -tiō,{/it} suffix of verbal action {ma}{mat|infect|}{/ma}
shortdef: the state produced by the establishment of one or more pathogenic agents (such as a bacteria, protozoans, or viruses) in or on the body of a suitable host
an act or process of infecting something or someone; also : the establishment of a pathogen in its host after invasion

dt: {bc}a persistent bacterial infection of some organ or region
{bc}one causing symptoms elsewhere in the body

shortdef: a persistent bacterial infection of some organ or region; especially : one causing symptoms elsewhere in the body

dt: {bc}a progressive painful disease of the mouth that is marked especially by dirty gray ulceration of the mucous membranes, bleeding of the gums, and a foul odor to the breath and that is associated with the presence of large numbers of a rod-shaped bacterium ({it}Fusobacterium fusiforme{/it} synonym {it}F. nucleatum{/it}) and a spirochete ({it}Treponema vincentii{/it} synonym {it}Borrelia vincentii{/it}) in the lesions

shortdef: a progressive painful disease of the mouth that is marked especially by dirty gray ulceration of the mucous membranes, bleeding of the gums, and a foul odor to the breath and that is associated with the presence of large numbers of a rod-shaped bacterium (Fusobacterium fusiforme synonym F. nucleatum) and a spirochete (Treponema vincentii synonym Borrelia vincentii) in the lesions —called also trench mouth

dt: {bc}infection of the vagina with an overgrowth of a normally present candidal fungus ({it}Candida albicans{/it}) that is characterized by a discharge and inflammation
{bc}an infection (such as thrush) caused by a yeast fungus or a yeast-like fungus

shortdef: infection of the vagina with an overgrowth of a normally present candidal fungus (Candida albicans) that is characterized by a discharge and inflammation; broadly : an infection (such as thrush) caused by a yeast fungus or a yeast-like fungus

dt: {bc}a sudden advance especially in knowledge or technique
{bc}an act or instance of moving through or beyond an obstacle

dt.t: a {wi}breakthrough{/wi} in the talks between the region's leaders

dt: {bc}an instance of passing through a barrier or protection

dt.t: The ice under the surface begins to deteriorate, increasing the risk of {wi}breakthroughs{/wi}.

dt: {bc}infection occurring in someone who is fully vaccinated against an infectious agent

dt.t: A vaccine {wi}breakthrough{/wi} occurs when a person tests positive for COVID-19 two weeks after being fully vaccinated against the disease …
Two other CDC studies of {phrase}breakthrough cases{/phrase} at nursing homes showed the vaccines protected residents, even when the virus spread through the homes.

… the academy recently recommended that children receive two doses of the chicken pox vaccine, rather than just one, because the additional dose bolsters immunity and may help reduce {phrase}breakthrough infection{/phrase}.

dt: {bc}an offensive military assault that penetrates and carries beyond a defensive line

shortdef: a sudden advance especially in knowledge or technique
a person's first notable success —often used before another noun
an act or instance of moving through or beyond an obstacle
